title: fix: sets `use_enum_values` to `True` to avoid problems with client `DatasetConfig` serialization
body:
# Description

I couldn't reproduce the error locally but looks like `use_enum_values` could potentially solve the problem:

```python
In [17]: class Response(BaseModel):
    ...:     status: ResponseStatus
    ...:

In [18]: Response(status=ResponseStatus.draft)
Out[18]: Response(status=<ResponseStatus.draft: 'draft'>)

In [19]: class Response(BaseModel):
    ...:     status: ResponseStatus
    ...:     class Config:
    ...:         use_enum_values = True
    ...:

In [20]: Response(status=ResponseStatus.draft)
Out[20]: Response(status='draft')
```

Closes #4089

title: feat: add new `metrics` module
body:
<!-- Thanks for your contribution! As part of our Community Growers initiative 🌱, we're donating Justdiggit bunds in your name to reforest sub-Saharan Africa. To claim your Community Growers certificate, please contact David Berenstein in our Slack community or fill in this form https://tally.so/r/n9XrxK once your PR has been merged. -->

# Description

This PR introduces a new module `argilla.client.feedback.metrics` to compute different metrics for a `FeedbackDataset`:

`argilla.client.feedback.metrics.annotator_metrics`
- [ ] For a given user, to compare its responses against the suggestions that were given. Depending on the type of question:
  - [x] `LabelQuestion`
  - [ ] `MultiLabelQuestion`
  - [x] `RatingQuestion`
  - [ ] `RankingQuestion`
  - [x] `TextQuestion`

   Example for a `FeedbackDataset` with 3 annotators:

   ```python
   dataset = FeedbackDataset(...)
   metric = AnnotatorMetric(dataset, "question-name")
   metrics_report = metric.compute(["gleu"])
   # >>> metrics_report
   # {'00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000001': [AnnotatorMetricResult(metric_name='gleu', result=0.16666666666666666)], 
   # '00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000002': [AnnotatorMetricResult(metric_name='gleu', result=0.25)],    
   # '00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000003': [AnnotatorMetricResult(metric_name='gleu', result=0.16666666666666666)]}
   # or a list of metrics
   metrics_report = metric.compute(["accuracy", "confusion-matrix"])
   ```

- [ ] To compare unified responses against the suggestions.
*In progress*

`argilla.client.feedback.metrics.inter_annotator_metrics`
*In progress*

Closes #4034

title: Add new `POST /api/v1/datasets/{dataset_id}/records/search` endpoint with vector search support for admin (SDK) operations
body:
# Description

This PR add the following changes:
* Handler function `search_dataset_records` has been renamed to `search_current_user_dataset_records`.
* Add a new `POST /api/v1/datasets/{dataset_id}/records/search` endpoint without current user context so it can be used to search for records by owners and admin and getting responses from all users.
* Add a new `search_records_with_all_responses` method for dataset policies v1 used by the new endpoint.
* Update SDK API to use this new endpoint instead of the old one with current user context.
* Some small refactors:
  * Improve order on some policies functions.
  * Fix problem with `limit` query param not including a lower limit of 1.
  * Fix problem with `limit` query param using `lte` inexistent parameter (instead of the right one `le`).

I'm adding as well a new test type where we focus in testing one specific endpoint. This test includes a class with two important aspects:
* A instance method `url` defining the `url` that is used for all the tests.
* Simple and isolated tests that don't use external helper functions.

Closes #4114

title: feat(integration): add support for `vectors` and `vectors_settings` in `{push_to,from)_huggingface`
body:
# Description

This PR adds support for the recently included `vectors` and `vectors_settings` at `FeedbackRecord` and `FeedbackDataset` level respectively. This means that the `vectors` can be stored and restored using `format_as("datasets")` via a `FeedbackDataset`, but also that the `vectors_settings` can be stored and restored as part of the `FeedbackDataset` settings when calling `push_to_huggingface` and `from_huggingface`, respectively.

Besides that also the `ArgillaDatasetCard` has been updated so as to include information about what's new!

Closes #4119

title: tests: Create a test reproducing the error
body:
<!-- Thanks for your contribution! As part of our Community Growers initiative 🌱, we're donating Justdiggit bunds in your name to reforest sub-Saharan Africa. To claim your Community Growers certificate, please contact David Berenstein in our Slack community or fill in this form https://tally.so/r/n9XrxK once your PR has been merged. -->

# Description

Listing records for a dataset using limits and offsets combined with multiple outer join results in missing record-related info. This is more evident using selective vectors (you can check the tests I pushed).  But in general, the `offset` and `limit` clauses are used before removing duplicated (`unique`), which means that some of the outer join enrichments are not applied after returning the records.


Closes #<issue_number>

To claim your Community Growers certificate, please contact David Berenstein in our Slack community or fill in this form https://tally.so/r/n9XrxK once your PR has been merged. -->

# Description

This PR supports fetching records with vectors from Python SDK. A new argument is provided in `from_argilla` method to provide which vectors must be downloaded with records (None by default). Users can set this argument to `all` to download all vectors found in the records.

title: fix: Support combining knn and filtering with OpenSearch
body:
<!-- Thanks for your contribution! As part of our Community Growers initiative 🌱, we're donating Justdiggit bunds in your name to reforest sub-Saharan Africa. To claim your Community Growers certificate, please contact David Berenstein in our Slack community or fill in this form https://tally.so/r/n9XrxK once your PR has been merged. -->

# Description

For OpenSearch engines, including boolean filters as part of the `knn` filter may return query phase errors if the response fields are not found in documents for the requested user (`responses.username.status = ...`). This is something that is not happening with Elasticsearch.

So, this PR fixes this by setting those query filters as a `post_filter` in the query. (This will potentially return less record than expected `k`, but it will be something to assume when using the OpenSearch engine.

title: chore: Upgrade minimal OpenSearch version to 2.6.0
body:
<!-- Thanks for your contribution! As part of our Community Growers initiative 🌱, we're donating Justdiggit bunds in your name to reforest sub-Saharan Africa. To claim your Community Growers certificate, please contact David Berenstein in our Slack community or fill in this form https://tally.so/r/n9XrxK once your PR has been merged. -->

# Description

Doing some tests with OpenSearch 2.5 I realized some cases where similarity search fails when adding as part of the `knn` filter an existing field clause (for user responses). This is documented and fixed in the Lucene 9.5.0 version (See here: https://github.com/apache/lucene/pull/12072). So the minimal required OpenSearch version must use the Lucene 9.5.0, which is 2.6.0.

Using versions under  2.6.0 an error `"failed to create query: Rewrite first"` using similarity search can be potentially raised.

title: feat: add SDK support for search records with similarity
body:
# Description

This PR suggest an implementation to give support to `/api/me/datasets/{dataset_id}/records/search` endpoint with vector similarity searching.

Here is a full example working with similarity search from python SDK using no real 100% fake data:
```python
rg.init(api_key=owner.api_key)
workspace = Workspace.create(name="test")

feedback_dataset.add_vector_settings(VectorSettings(name="vector", dimensions=2))

feedback_dataset.add_records(
    [
        FeedbackRecord(fields={"text": "hello"}, vectors={"vector": [1, 1]}),
        FeedbackRecord(
            fields={"text": "hello"},
            vectors={"vector": [2, 2]},
            responses=[ResponseSchema(status="discarded")],
        ),
        FeedbackRecord(
            fields={"text": "hello"},
            vectors={"vector": [4, 4]},
            responses=[ResponseSchema(status="submitted", values={"question": {"value": "answer"}})],
        ),
    ]
)

remote = feedback_dataset.push_to_argilla("test_find_similar_records", workspace=workspace)
only_submitted_and_discarded_records = remote.filter_by(response_status=["submitted", "discarded"])

records_with_scores = only_submitted_and_discarded_records.find_similar_records(
    vector_name="vector",
    value=[1, 1],
    max_results=3,
)
# Even if the used vector is the same that contains the record 0, the search will skip it since it has no submitted or discarded responses.
```

Closes #4020

**Type of change**

- [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

**How Has This Been Tested**

# Description

In this PR the `POST /api/v1/datasets/:dataset_id/records` endpoint is modified to support vector creation. The `vectors` attribute is an optional dictionary where the key is the vector (settings) name and the value is the vector value.

The changes included here are based on PR #3799, but only apply the record creation modifications. Future PRs will include listing records with vector info and updating records with vector info, but separately, since a lot of non-trivial changes must by applied.

Refs #3799

title: feature: search records using vectors
body:
<!-- Thanks for your contribution! As part of our Community Growers initiative 🌱, we're donating Justdiggit bunds in your name to reforest sub-Saharan Africa. To claim your Community Growers certificate, please contact David Berenstein in our Slack community or fill in this form https://tally.so/r/n9XrxK once your PR has been merged. -->

# Description

This PR updates the endpoint `POST /api/me/datasets/:dataset_id/records/search` to accept vector searches:
```bash
POST /api/me/datasets/:dataset_id/records/search
{
  "query": {
    "vector": {
      "name": "my-vector-name",
      "record_id": ...,
      "order": "most_similar"
    }
  }
}
````

Also, the minimal OpenSearch version has been upgraded to 2.5, since versions <=2.4 do not support filtering + similarity search properly.

Finally, the default Argilla search engine is configured to Elasticsearch (⚠️  this change may affect users using OpenSearch)

## TODO
- [x] Add missing tests
- [x] Filter using metadata + response status 
- [x] Apply most/least similarity order
- [x] Validations (record exists by id)
- [x] Adding search text as filter

PR https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pull/4043 must be merged before

Refs: https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/issues/3028

title: Fix: add metadata property for datasets without metadata properties already defined
body:
<!-- Thanks for your contribution! As part of our Community Growers initiative 🌱, we're donating Justdiggit bunds in your name to reforest sub-Saharan Africa. To claim your Community Growers certificate, please contact David Berenstein in our Slack community or fill in this form https://tally.so/r/n9XrxK once your PR has been merged. -->

# Description

This PR fixes this workflow:
```python
ds = rg.FeedbackDataset.for_supervised_fine_tuning(
    context=True,
    use_markdown=True,
    guidelines=None,
    #metadata=metadata # I've just created a feature request for this
)
​
# In the meantime I want to update a dataset I've just created
metadata = [rg.TermsMetadataProperty(name="one_of_my_col", title="One of my col")]
for m in metadata:
  ds.add_metadata_property(m)
```

The `__init__` method defines an empty list for `_metadata_properties` attribute if `None` was passed. Otherwise, an error occurs when adding a new metadata property.

title: feat: add `last_activity_at` to feedback datasets
body:
# Description

This PR adds a new `DateTime` column to `datasets` table with name `last_activity_at`.

This new column will be updated for the following cases:
* When a dataset is created or updated.
* When a response for a record belonging to the dataset has been created, updated or deleted.

The idea is that we can use `last_activity_at` to record the last time that an activity associated with a dataset happened and use it instead of `updated_at` to show recent activity on the UI.

Closes #3981
